Looking at the second row again: Essendon's score is 15.15 (105), which means they scored 15 goals and 15 behinds, totaling 105 points. Richmond scored 16.19 (115). So, Essendon got 105 points, and Richmond got 115.

But based solely on this table, we have one match at Windy Hill where Essendon scored 105 and Richmond 115. So, in that particular game, the away team (Richmond) scored more points than the home team (Essendon). But since Windy Hill is just a venue, it doesn't accumulate points; rather, the teams do.

Therefore, the claim seems to be misinterpreted because venues don't have points; teams do. So, the correct interpretation might be whether the team playing at Windy Hill had the most points in their game or overall. However, without knowing other games, we can't confirm if that single game was the highest for either team.

But given the information, it's clear that in the match at Windy Hill on May 18, Richmond scored more than Essendon, but that doesn't mean Windy Hill itself got any points. So, the claim is incorrectly attributing points to a venue instead of teams.
